review.title: Activity Modeling in Smart Home using High Utility Pattern Mining over Data Streams
review.abstract: Smart home technology is a better choice for the people to care about security, comfort and power saving as well. It is required to develop technologies that recognize the Activities of Daily Living (ADLs) of the residents at home and detect the abnormal behavior in the individual's patterns. Data mining techniques such as Frequent pattern mining (FPM), High Utility Pattern (HUP) Mining were used to find those activity patterns from the collected sensor data. But applying the above technique for Activity Recognition from the temporal sensor data stream is highly complex and challenging task. So, a new approach is proposed for activity recognition from sensor data stream which is achieved by constructing Frequent Pattern Stream tree (FPS - tree). FPS is a sliding window based approach to discover the recent activity patterns over time from data streams. The proposed work aims at identifying the frequent pattern of the user from the sensor data streams which are later modeled for activity recognition. The proposed FPM algorithm uses a data structure called Linked Sensor Data Stream (LSDS) for storing the sensor data stream information which increases the efficiency of frequent pattern mining algorithm through both space and time. The experimental results show the efficiency of the proposed algorithm and this FPM is further extended for applying for power efficiency using HUP to detect the high usage of power consumption of residents at smart home.

sections.text: The proposed FPM algorithm uses a data structure called Linked Sensor Data Stream (LDS) for the development of technologies that detect the activities of daily life (ADLs) of residents at home and detect abnormal behavior in individual patterns. Data mining techniques such as Frequent Pattern Mining (FPM), High Utility Pattern (HUP) Mining have been used to find these activity patterns from the collected sensor data. However, applying the above technique for activity detection from the temporal sensor data stream is a highly complex and challenging task. Therefore, a new approach for activity detection from the sensor data stream is proposed, which is achieved by constructing the frequency pattern from the sensor stream (FPS - tree). FPS is a sliding window-based approach to detect the most recent activity patterns over time from data streams. The proposed work aims to identify the frequent pattern of the user from the sensor stream data (FPS - tree) used by the sensor algorithm for determining the activity streams from the sensor stream (the sensor stream) to be used later by the PM for the sensor stream structure.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Ambient Assisted Living is an emerging area that focuses on helping older people function independently at home. Smart Home is the combination of technology and services through the process of connectivity that is established at home for a better quality of life [1]. The need for such technology is due to the ageing population, high quality of life, costly formal health care and the importance of residents accommodating others in their own homes. Smart Home helps residents to improve living comfort, convenience, safety and energy management [2] [11]. A smart home appears "intelligent" because its computer systems can monitor so many aspects of daily life. Residents must complete their activities of daily life (ADLs) [15], such as eating, dressing, sleeping, cooking, etc. Monitoring activities makes it possible to detect the adverse situations that residents are exposed to that can trigger an emergency mechanism. [16] It is necessary to discover the common user behavior and predict their future actions in the home.

sections.heading: 2. Related Work
sections.text: There are two types of pattern mining such as Frequent Pattern Mining and High Utility Pattern Mining [4]. Various algorithms are proposed to find these common patterns. Apriori was the basic algorithm to find common patterns of activity that were proposed by R.Agrawal andR.Srikant in 1994 [5]. This algorithm uses prior knowledge to find out the common patterns. Downward trait is used to crop the rare patterns. If a pattern is rare, then all its superpatterns must be rare. Frequent pattern mining is the process of finding frequent patterns of activity from the input sensor data stream [3].

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Results
sections.text: The experimental results as shown in Fig. 6 show the frequent patterns of the activities of the daily life (ADLs) of the occupant, which are recognized by the intelligent environment and used in the activity modeling. Fig. 7 shows the high use patterns of the activities of daily life (ADLs) of the occupant, who uses extreme energy (utilities) in the domestic environment. Such information about the detection of anomalies is communicated to the user or caregiver.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: The proposed algorithms increased the efficiency of the frequent sample mining. The extended work focused on determining the high electricity consumption of residents in the home environment and also helping them to use resources more efficiently.
